column12: HOL_IMP Comments
column13: General Comments

column12: Holacracy has done some good but on the other hand we sugar-coat things and people are not really being held accountable for their work.
column13: My experience at iQ has been great. I do the work that is required of me and more. I always held myself accountable for my actions thus great productivity to get the work done even if that means working tons of overtime. My Lead has been a major factor with my push. I think that there should be some sort of compensation for numerous overtime as my mentality is I get the work done regardless of pay compensation and if I do for long periods, there should be some reward. A company does not want to have their employee saying they will not work long hours to get what is required done and meet deadlines for reason of not getting rewarded. We tend to be blind by politics in the company thus overlooking issues some employees have.

column12: Yes and no.  Some areas have improved greatly, others seem to use Holacracy as a get out of jail free card. "It's not my accountability" or "that's not my job" is heard a lot.
column13: All comments, from every survey should be taken seriously.  It is illegal to have your employees work overtime with no compensation.  It is also unfair to pick and choose which teams receive overtime compensation.  Titles matter, seniority is considered here, stop saying it's not, there absolutely are favorites here and we all see it.  Remember the little people.  Politics are everywhere, even at iQ, saying they aren't and not addressing the problem doesn't make it go away.
i would like more feedback on my performance and how to improve in any way i can in my role

Receiving regular feedback from your lead is vital to your success. When you are not receiving that feedback because the Lead Link is too busy or overwhelmed it slows the developmental process. Regular feedback is vital to my success at iQmetrix and as a person.

column12: Holocracy provides our meetings with a great deal of flexibility and brings clarity to our roles and how we resolve issues
column13: I feel that leadership is open about the goals of the company and encourage employee participation

column12: I'm newly hired and Holacracy was already established. It is pretty different from what I'm used to but I like what I've seen so far.

It has definitely improved many aspects of the way we operate, but there are still influences outside our control that are directly affecting our ability to deliver on our purpose. This may only affect my team specifically because we are governed by a contract that limits the number of resources the client will pay for and holacrtacy does not provide a way for us to self-manage external clients. We always have top follow what the contract says even if we disagree with it.
column13: Still a great place to work, however the formality of Holacracy has had an impact on culture it seems. I appreciate the focus on better fiscal responsibility, but it was a bit discouraging to see a conversation in slack on the topic of training. A single developer from a given team was very interested in participating in a local development conference, but the lead was still evaluating whether that learning opportunity could be justified in terms of benefit to the team and cost/budget with the circle... Telling someone they can't pursue a learning opportunity because there isn't concrete evidence that it will directly benefit the team doesn't really feel like we're investing in our people... But maybe that's an unfair perspective

column12: Still not sure, once everyone buys in and all circles and roles are treated the way they should be, then I feel it will help improve iQ but right now we dont have enough buy-in from all leads and some circles still do not have the ability to set their own priorities. Those circles are still being told from different executives what is most important.
column13: Overall I think iQ is amazing, but we need the buy in and support from higher levels to make sure holacracy works. We have a really solid start but we need all circles to be on the same page before we will see the true benefits of it. Also I think we need to re-think the lead link role. I personally feel it should not be your decision makers or best tech lead. It needs to be a person that is able to lead the circle and make sure things are going smooth and on track. There are a lot of people in the role that are having trouble balancing the lead link roles with Project manager and tech lead roles. These people are getting over stressed and the Lead link role could be used by someone who will find the answers not the one that knows them. We lose too much time with good developers not actually developing because they are tied up in other non technical meetings or chats. Just my two cents.

column12: Having clear definitions of what you are accountable for is great.The "silo-ing" of roles is bad. It's hard to distribute work fairly this way.

column13: Its been the best Canadian company I have worked for. Management should continue doing what they are doing.
It would be nice to be able to work from home on a regular basis.

column12: I think everyone has improved except for our Executive layer.
column13: I feel as though our company would be progressing much faster with a technological strategy and tighter clarity brought about by a present Executive.  All things considered, we have a COO driving business strategy and that's it from an Executive perspective ... I never hear from the CEO or CTO. That's not helpful when we're trying to have Enterprise companies (whether client or partner) believe in what we're striving towards as a business.

column12: I think IQ needs a new management process that works, I don't believe Holacracy is the way to do it. Its only good for documenting people and roles.
We need more broad adoption - specifcally below the lead link level
column13: I appreciate the continous work to get better. We definitely aren't there yet - but I do believe we care to ensure that we are constantly moving in the right direction.
There is a lack of diffusion of passion about our purpose as an organization

column12: There is more clarity in roles than ever before, yet it is still not perfect. There are days when I see obvious positive examples of things that I believe never would have happened before Holacracy, but there are also days when I encounter the same old frustrations of roadblocks that have not changed one bit since adopting Holacracy. So, overall I agree that we're better, because I don't think Holacracy has actually broken anything, it's just highlighted areas where we still need to improve, but haven't yet.
column13: I realize (and am a total believer) that ideas to grow iQmetrix can and should come from anyone in the organization, but we're lacking the language and specificity for where what we're trying to achieve as a company to help guide those ideas... so some ideas get too far down the path before it becomes clear that they are steering us off course and then some ideas never get off the ground that I think could actually help us.

column12: It amazes me that we were functioning at all, without it. Holacracy has enabled people who normally wouldn't have talked, to meet regularly and voice their own tensions. I don't think people feel as alone as they used to when they're frustrated or have an issue. Holacracy always seems to offer a way forward, providing the next logical step that generally focuses on the work and desired outcomes. It's also teaching us to tackle more immediate issues to chip away at the bigger problems. I do sometimes feel that Holacracy lacks a structure that lets you see the big organizational picture. Cross-circle communication suffers as a result.
column13: We're losing good people in an industry where a growing number of companies are allowing employees to work remotely. The bigger we get, the more 'corporate stiffening" seems to occur. It feels like we're turning into those companies we used to make fun of.

column12: Its like walking into an office of smiling zombies. Nobody knows what they are doing anymore or why. It seems like every one is doing their best to stay employed but no one is working for the same end-goal. We don't always know what the goals are anymore. Holocracy has replaced hearts.
column13: We exist. We are trying to do our best work but its not easy when the goal and purposes is different every week for every group.

column12: The company is definitely making strides forward.  Old habits die hard, we need to pay attention to the circles who are always trying to get others to do the heavy lifting of their grand ideas.
column13: What a blessing, I am not so obtuse to think any company is perfect.  But having the ability to discover who I am and the ability to pursue my passions has made me a happier calmer person.  What I have found though is the more I help others, the happier I am.   I still have goals to work on but, know the company I work for will support those goals.

Although majority rules, I think that so far iQmetrix has listened to situations where alternative solutions are needed and responded well. I think as we go forward as a company, flexibility around benefits and compensation will be important and key to employee satisfaction.

column12: In my situation I am siloed in my work which makes it less engaging, but holacracy makes sense for the amount of work I have in my roles. The clarity of what you should be working on is by far the best trait of holacracy.
We now have mechanisms to address tensions and while Holocracy is able to take care of some issues, it helps exacerbate others like being efficient.

I am very much looking forward to the roll out of the compensation strategy. Not everyone performs the same so its fair that people shouldn't be rewarded the same. I know what my limitations are and where my contribution level is. I also know where I need to improve and the feedback from my lead and my team is information I will hopefully put into a positive action. There have been many changes that continue to advance the company forward. The fact that these changes stem from these surveys and conversations with employees at all levels of company is very encouraging.
column13: I am very much looking forward to the roll out of the contribution and compensation strategy. Not everyone performs the same so its fair that people shouldn't be rewarded the same. I know what my limitations are and where my contribution level is. I also know where I need to improve and the feedback from my lead and my team is information I will hopefully put into a positive action. There have been many changes all positive and productive changes to continue the company's advance forward. The fact that these changes stem from these surveys and conversation with employees at all levels of company is very encouraging. The trust we all have in each other is amazing, it isn't common in the workplace. No one is boxed in or stereotyped, being empowered to do your job as you see fit or to fill several roles based on talent is incredible. I am excited about these next years and where this company will go.

column12: I joined when holocracy was adopted. Not sure what it was like before I joined
column13: Be careful not to overwork your employees

column12: Holacracy helps the communication. The ability to escalate problems to departments beyond workgroup can bring visibility to problems that otherwise didn't receive attention before.  This may not always result in the outcomes you desire but having larger circles above yours hear a complaint or suggestion is better than feeling completely ignored.

There is now a lot of "that's not my circle's role" going on.  We should all be trying to work together.  Some duties are not assigned to a circle...yet.  That shouldn't be an excuse for not doing the work.
column13: This has not happened to me personally, but there are others in my group that stay up all night working on issues for clients, but never get any recognition for it.  This leads to bad morale and eventually turnover.  If employees are putting in extra time and are always up for the job, they should be recognized for that.

column12: For my team, holacracy didn't change anything, it just added an hour long tactical meeting each week. In my circle, tactical meetings and our weekly scrum meetings (which we did before holacracy) overlap and I feel it's a waste of time to have both.

Even if some aspects of holocracy don't really make sense (or work 100%) for some of the things our circle does, it has definitely made people more aware and more conscious about what they do and how it impacts the goals on the company. In my mind that is worth its weight in gold.

I did not work for iQmetrix without Holacracy, but I can say that I enjoy this system of management and collaboration far more than any other I have encountered. Even being in a simple volunteer board meeting makes me wish Holacracy was common practice for both inside and outside of the professional office setting.
column13: The sense of support and trust I've felt from my peers since entering my work at iQmetrix is noticeable and appreciated. I've never been apprehensive to voice my opinion or concern, and constructive feedback is given in a way that allows for me to grow, rather than linger of past mistakes.

column12: I wasn't here before Holacracy so I can't say for sure. My teammates seems to like it.
column13: Though currently it seems as though processes are still being worked out, ultimately it seems to be heading in the right direction.  I'm not actually clear on what process or criteria are used to evaluate my contribution (other than peer feedback).

column12: Holacracy has improved iQmetrix in terms of it forcing everyone to be accountable for their esponsibilities, but I don't really buy into it anymore since there are clearly a good number of departments ignoring it. It's too hard following Holacracy and non-Holacracy processes at the same time to get work done.
column13: Why does it seem like senior leadership has been deliberately segmented from the rest of the organization? And we continue to shed all kinds of employees. Are we actually having financial issues? Are we really acquiring someone since forever ago? Should we all be stressed about iQmetrix's slow decline? Or should I simply keep focusing on my Product Market's health and ignore iQmetrix's problems?

column12: There is greater clarity and visibility into the structure of the organization
column13: Sometimes, what we say and what we do are at odds with each other. I know we aren't perfect, and necessarily can't be, but this is an area to work on.

column12: I have not been here long enough to determine this. Holacracy does have some good values from what I have been a part of.
column13: iQ is a great place to work. The people are great. The culture is even better! I hope we are able to keep sustaining this as the company grows.

column12: I think Holacracy has the power to address many of the issues faced at iQmetrix. However, in my personal experience those who completely disregard Holacracy do not seem to face any consequence at all. The non-adopters aren't actually collaborating, they are just using the holacracy language to impose their will on others.
column13: Negative team environments at iQmetrix seem to survive much longer than I would expect at any other company. Many sub-optimal or nearly failing projects are not addressed and are allowed to continue nearly failing instead of just failing and trying again. As a consequence a lot of team members are disengaged with their product, team and stakeholders on everyday work.

column12: Unfortunately the "not my or my circle's accountability" comes up far too often and acts as a blocker. Some people have taken holacracy to an extreme and provide no value and have become near useless by spending time redirecting people to others rather than simply helping out the person and keep things moving along.
column13: iQmetrix does not stand out or apart from other companies. As it stands there is no significant reason for someone to choose iQmetrix over any other company. Particularly in Vancouver where iQmetrix has to compete against many other companies whose appearance on one's CV is far more valuable than having iQmetrix listed. With Ubisoft opening an office in Winnipeg, there is now a very interesting and fun option for developers to pursue.

column12: Circles are a really nice to look at and organize people. Tacticals just feel like they cost me time though.
column13: I would love to see a focus on User Experience, right now it feels like we're not making great looking/feeling experiences and there is not a focus on that. Winnipeg feels like it's bleeding talent lately.

column12: It is still a work in progress.

I feel Holacracy has created stronger impenetrable silos that have made it even harder to work together across teams. My team builds a product that relies on another product in order for it to work properly, but that other department is now so separate and independent from my department that they may as well be on Mars.
column13: Find a way to make it so different departments work together more efficiently.

column12: I was not here before Holocracy, so I have nothing to compare it to. I do feel it works very well though!
column13: I have grown immensely in my abilities here. I'm excited for all the possible opportunities I have in growing with this company.

column12: We are still a long way from solving our past issues with Holacracy.  The problems we had in the company weren't directly addressed by broad changes such as a Holocracy implementation.  Also the same people who were managers before are pretty much filling the lead link roles even though we're told that role isn't about being a manager. How do I tell a person who was assigning me work last year that "thanks but I assign my own work now"? I don't feel Holocracy has directly impacted any outcomes.
column13: Its great, but there are still issues.

column12: Slowly but surely we are getting there. I think there are different areas or departments that have adopted Holacracy but there are still individuals who still want to do what they want. And it seems that these people are in leadership positions and who have been with the company for 6+ years.
column13: They need to know that in order for this company to grow that sometimes you cannot keep doing what you have always been doing or are used to. You must get used to change and accept the new way of how things are moving forward. Be more engaging with others in your office. It seems some leaders are more introverted now or do not want to have anything to do with anyone for whatever reason I do not know.  This does not make others feel good.
It is hard to know how to contribute more from where i actually am

column12: I was hired after the adoption, and therefore have no point of reference. Seems to work though.
While I believe that iQ as a company has benefitted, smaller tight knit teams have not.
Information is being passed more freely, but there needs to be more work done on having holacracy implemented consistently in all the teams..

Holacracy hasn't delivered the clarity and autonomy I expected.  Roles and accountabilities were established early, they have not changed since we started the implementation, and they seem to be outdated and inaccurate now.  We're supposed to raise tensions around this, but it hasn't really come up.  There is nobody to blame but myself I suppose, but it just feels like yet another thing to do and think about when I'm busy enough already.

column13: Teams are continuing to work in isolation and, as a result, there is continual overlap in work done. Different teams do the same work, tackle the same projects, come up with different solutions, and only realize when they clash. So much time has been wasted by teams doubling up unnecessarily on work.

column12: I applaud the company for trying new things. But there has not been any evaluation yet about whether holacracy is actually working for teams. For the teams that follow the Agile process, holacracy has been an additional burden because of the overlap (ie. tactical meeting) with the Agile meetings. Also, "not my responsibility" is often heard more. Luckily, there are still people who help each out when they can, but there are people who holacracy to escape responsibilities. It would be great to see the company do a full evaluation of holcracy and evaluate if it's actually useful or not. And if it isn't, how can it be improved or do we need to consider a different structure.
column13: A lot of great people in the company!

I have always found the culture and people at IQ to be amazing. It is a wonderful place to start your career and you feel like a part of a family here. However as you grow in the company and take on more responsibilities the wages do not grow enough to match. I feel this lack of competitive compensation has resulted in many senior and more talented people leaving the company for greener pastures. I hope to have many more years in this company but as time goes on I worry if I may need to find somewhere else to work to have a comfortable living wage.

When I started at iQmetrix it was a very confusing work environment and very technically orientated.  As a Business driven person I was not feeling a strong fit.  In the last year there has been a shift towards more of a business focus and I now feel I have a purpose and stronger fit here.  There is still a gap in the support that is provided for non technical people which I hope improves.

column12: In general things seem to be as chaotic as ever, processes seem slower and driving change is harder and more political as teams all follow their own agendas.  We seem much less united by common goals and purposes.  We need more oversight because individual teams seem too busy to coordinate anything beyond their own strategies.
column13: It feels to me like there are strong strategic directions we should be heading toward and improvements that should be done.  I know my own project should be managed better but there does not seem to be time to focus on that when there is always a fire or something more important to get done everywhere.  I know we don't always follow best practices and I wish we had time to.  Things that cause massive frustration and overhead are usually external to our team and usually involve trying to coax work out of another team or individual.  As we get larger we are less and less in control of everything within our projects and it would be very helpful to have someone above teams driving directives and setting priorities.

column12: Yes and no -- I feel as though Holocracy has improved our processes from before - it's been great -  but I also feel as though more needs to be done to fully have the staff understand Holocracy to use it to its full effectiveness. Rather than having a bunch of meetings that people don't feel are useful, we want the tactical meetings to create a strong positive influence in the work we do.
column13: It's been great.

column12: Everything is so much more clear than at this time last year.  The implementation process has been bumpy, and I disagree with a lot of the choices that were made, but we've come out way ahead overall and I'm excited about the current trajectory.
column13: I love my job, I'm excited to come into work every day, and I feel like the work I'm doing matters.  Holacracy has amplified that feeling 10-fold, because it gives me the tools to pick the work I think is most valuable, and the permission to feel guilt-free about the work that is lower priority and not getting done and the safety to be transparent about it.  My biggest issue currently is that many Lead Links have only received 1 hour of training, however they are expected to be the "face" of holacracy to their circles, and many of them just want to get the work of their circle done, and aren't really interested in working on team development.  I wish that they knew that they had the option to hand off the role of working on the circle to somebody who might like it better, so that they could focus on the work of the circle instead.

column12: Holacracy makes our roles and accountabilities clearer. I find it easier to clearly ask for work when I'm not busy.
I was not with iQ prior to Holacracy but compared to my last job I like the system.

I see some areas where we have improvement and some areas where it's been confusing and holacracy affected the speed we move forward at. I think once we are through the implementation phase it will be better, but I wouldn't say we have improved yet.
column13: It's interesting... holocracy is forcing me to have to collaborate more as it specifies who should actually do something (and as such, that I should not be the one to do it), in the past, if there was an obstacle I would just do it myself, now that doesn't go over so well. I would find that I would end up with really engaged and talented individuals all with a passion for a project - because the roles just grew out of the need in a particular project, so it was self-organizing. Now if there is a project/initiative - you have to try to build the vision around the goal, because people are just contributing to the goal because it's part of their accountabilities, not because they care about the goal.  I'm finding I have to be more of a cheerleader and constantly pitch the vision to get people excited/driven/motivated to move forward - whereas before the teams I worked with would just want to get it done.  I feel like holacracy is making it so we don't rally around a goal or a common cause, but rather just pluck away at the things we are accountable for.  I miss working with teams that just showed up with a drive to get the thing done... it felt more exciting and meaningful. On the flip side, I find myself having to consciously make efforts to get people excited and to care about the work in a meaningful way - it's forcing me to practice my leadership skills in a covert way. Since I don't really see myself as being in a leadership role at iQmetrix, it's kind of interesting to practice the skills. Keeps me entertained anyways.

column12: I think it has improved overall, I do think there are a number of people using holacracy as a method for not doing things, but that's not because of holacracy.
column13: I think we should try and do less because at the moment we are trying to do to much. I am really excited about the company investing in the core product and think the "new" organizational structure is a great idea.

column12: I still don't notice a large day-to-day change outside of tacticals.
column13: I worry about current health and stability. I am aware of a number of teams that are under-resourced and propped up by the extraordinary efforts often of just one person. This is a recipe for a number of localized crises.

Slow down. Stop trying to run when you don't know how to walk; especially if running has failed you already. Think objectively and realize that maybe running first was a bad idea, and that learning to walk was probably a good idea.

column12: I feel like the more explicit our accountabilities the better we become overall. I think we are getter better at shedding light on unsung heroes who do far more than they have previously been given credit for. It's not perfect yet, but we're going in the right direction.
column13: As a developer role the contribution evaluations between intermediate and senior need to be addressed. My lead link has been in the process of trying to bump me up in level, but the contribution guidelines are skewed in that you need to be influencing the entirety of the company and/or be a lead yourself. The contribution guidelines need room for technically strong, development-focused roles that don't necessarily require revolutionary output. Each circle needs its own experts too and they need to be compensated for that appropriately

column12: Overall agree that holacracy has been a benefit but the adoption and how it is followed is inconsistent between teams.

column13: Overall I love working at iQ, but feel that we need better feedback and clearer structure on how to personally grow within the company whether that's in our own role or looking to transition to others and use our skillsets most effectively for the good of the company.

column12: Holacracy as a tool has not improved the company.  The new structure isn't giving us better direction, better leadership, or better communication.
column13: I see a significant lack of transparency and integrity around the decisions made here.  Ownership of mistakes is basically non-existent at the leadership level, we just keep doubling down and crossing our fingers that maybe someday it will work out.

column12: Holacracy is a double edged sword. People rely on the Holacracy rules to strictly and rigidly define their role, which is detrimental to flexibility. However, doing it this way has created transparency and a set of accountabilities for people to focus on and grow into.
column13: Expect Less; Experience More

We as a company still carry so much dead weight. There are so many people here just sit on their ass and browse the internet all day everyday. There are also many incompetent people in mid-management roles just because they've been here forever, and way over paid. They have not updated their skills, industry knowledge or even work ethic for years, for some of the smaller teams they are detrimental for team growth, and the personal career growth for others.
I need an increase in pay

column12: I cannot see any improvement.

I feel overall we have improved thanks to holacracy, but I feel like for most people the feeling of empowerment and autonomy holacracy promised has not been realized. I frequently hear from others, including lead links, that that don't feel like they can say "no" and that projects and deadlines are thrust upon them and they and their teams have to work extra hard and sometimes even overtime to meet deadlines that they never had input in themselves.
column13: When I first started at iQmetrix people only left because they were following a spouse to a new city or occasionally to pursue a unique employment opportunity elsewhere. Within the last year that has changed. People have been leaving because there are things they are dissatisfied with within iQmetrix. Hopefully those reasons have been clear in their exit surveys and we're acting on them, but there are serious resourcing issues within iQmetrix already and losing valuable, highly skilled and experienced staff only exacerbates those issues. There are already teams that have been chronically understaffed and not allowed to hire the people they need. The root causes of people leaving need to be addressed immediately and the other resourcing shortfalls need to be resolved ASAP if we're to begin making positive progress and restore confidence with all of our staff.

column12: I wasn't here before Holocracy so I don't have means to know if the company was improved or not after the adoption. It seems to work OK though.
column13: The company is amazing but sometimes I feel a lack of support in better understanding the boundaries between my work and others' work.

column12: I disagree that -Holacracy- has improved our company. Instead, I think the adoption process simply brought to light structural issues and implicit responsibilities that people had. The kind of introspection we needed to do (and still need to do) is more to do with figuring out our departmental problems ourselves so we that we have the information to organize ourselves into Holacracy. Holacractic practices haven't really had an impact, in my opinion.
column13: I love the people here, and I've really enjoyed working and learning with them. However, I'm worried about the long term-health of our product and iQmetrix as a company.

column12: We traded in some of our morale for (potentially) improved efficiency.  The changeover was helpful as a reminder that I work for a large, profit-driven company.
column13: Transparency is super important! If you have to make changes that you think people won't like, own up to it. If you only tout transparency when things are going well, you breed a culture of distrust.

I love working here. I don't feel like I am compensated well enough though. I feel like no matter how hard I work or how much my influence/responsibilities increase over the years,  the highest raise I can expect is 4% which barely passes cost of living increases each year.

column12: I don't think my circle embraced holocracy as much as the rest of the company, so I don't see it playing a significant role. I also don't think we adhere to it properly, my account abilities have changed three times this year alone and rhis has never been reflected in Glassfrog. It's hard to take this seriously or see the benefit when my lead link does not follow the process.
column13: Being heavily micro-managed has alienated me from feeling autonomy or ownership over my work. I still love working here and see great potential in the team, but without ability to make my own decisions and grow or fail by taking risks, I don't see a lot of sustainability here, which sucks because I think I do great work, always get positive feedback, and have really good ideas to contribute. I love the team and believe we still attract great talent. The issue is retaining that talent on this team.
I appreciate the level of trust given to us to let us work without the micromanagement.

column12: I think Holocracy has brought a much needed push for clarity within iQ. I don't think holacracy is integrated enough yet that one can really 'trust the system' to support you if your Lead Link isn't adopting holocracy fully.
column13: Executive team still needs to drastically improve communication. Tell people about important issues repeatedly until no one is asking anymore.

column12: It might be me, but I think we have more roles and work with holacracy and although we can drop roles I do not feel comfortable doing that, so we might end up being overloaded.
column13: It's been amazing working for IQ. My leadership is always straightforward and clear. Also very welcoming and accommodating. I feel my needs are heard. I would, however, improve culture to be more accountable for making things done based on defined processes.

column12: I don't believe the company has improved significantly under holacracy but the program has some good parts
column13: I am concerned about the culture and the things that made the culture what it was or is are slowly being eroded.  Is Culture as important to the decision makers as it used to be?
Good people are leaving faster the company faster than we can replace them. I am worried about the turnover.
I've always felt encouraged to grow and learn at iQmetrix.

The process requiring us to post all jobs internally (and not just move people into new roles) is prohibitive and makes us lose some of the benefit of Holacracy. I think teams need the autonomy to fills roles and post job listings as they see fit (within the budget of course).

column12: I remain skeptical because that's who I am (and I'd be a poor QA if I wasn't) but, I can see that over time Holacracy has started to help my circle function better by making both strong and weak players more visible.
column13: I think within my circle things are finally starting to change for the better. Strong performers are getting more roles and accountabilities, weak performers are getting feedback that wasn't as forthcoming before. Additionally, the whole circle is getting more recognition for the late nights we regularly have to put in to support each release, hopefully that translates to more than just extra snacks and booze with the new initiatives that are coming.

column12: Need to see hard evidence that the new model helping us do better at investing our resources and serving our customers.  Until our core metrics reflect a clear turnaround I can't say Holacracy is a clear win.

column13: It feels like there's been improvement since last summer but I'm concerned about the efforts in keeping our valuable people here at iQ. We've lost some incredibly strong members of our office which is concerning to say the least.

column12: I don't think Holocracy has improved my day to day here at iQmetrix. I honestly never track or update my projects, it is just more project tracking, which I already track using my own system.
column13: Please please please open your eyes to the cliques and political hierarchy functioning in this otherwise great company. It seems like the people moving up are those who are chummy with certain people, the golden children of iQmetrix who can't seem to do no wrong. [Even when they've done some very sketchy and questionable things], while those of us who just work with our heads down and don't 'drink the kool aid' are left in the dust. I see a lot of inappropriate conversations and actions, and even though they're reported they don't get disciplined due to their standing as a 'golden child/cool kid/whatever you'd like to call them'. Those of us that work hard, keep our head down and don't kiss up to those higher ups don't get the same opportunities, or recognition for our hard work. I hope things change soon, as people are starting to quit due to the politics of the company.

column12: N/A I was hired after the adoption.

I've seen some stuff that has improved, like giving space to people that don't normally feel like they can express their thoughts. Also the idea of respecting everyone as the expert of their own role, giving autonomy to everyone is a positive step. Other stuff has been hindered, in my opinion, such as adding process steps that seem unnecessary but that you can't criticize. I've heard facilitators saying "some processes are optional, but if you are not part of it, then maybe you don't want to be part of iQmetrix, since it chose that as the organizational structure." which might seem like either a warning or emotional blackmail.
column13: Feedback is fundamental in any relationship. And iQmetrix seems to strive for it, but so far I've only received one suggestion of improvement and I doubt that there are not other areas where people perceive I could improve. Some of the people that has been let go claim that they never received feedback for them to improve, they just got the notice that they were not a good fit; which I believe is not what iQmetrix wants to aim for. Additionally, iQmetrix gives lead links the opportunity to decide on the compensation for the circle member but then it gets debated and tried to get reduced when it has been thought that the circle member should be compensated better than average. I think this discourages lead links to go through the effort and pushes them to evaluate everyone as average, lowering the morale of the person being evaluated.

column12: I believe holacracy has improved communication across different teams, and has defined a process that allows people to work on projects where they are both interested and can add value. I think there is a very large flaw in the compensation strategy though because some individuals are fulfilling multiple roles but not compensated for it. This needs to be addressed.

We are more fragmented than ever.  There are still many unfilled roles with work just being expected, inconsistent expectations about how roles are filled, who is accountable, and little transparency of the processes, at all levels
column13: I am not confident that we address the main concerns that face the company.  Despite many surveys and feedback given, it appears that some of the main issue are dismissed or ignored.  We have always claimed to pride ourselves on our transparency, visibility, growth opportunities and support of employees, however this doesn't seem to be the focus.  Employees are constantly taken advantage of and expected to do more than is reasonable.  Decision making and the process leading to decisions is not visible to all.  There is not enough input or consideration for employees, especially considering we operate with employees shares.  There should be more accountability at all levels for the decisions made.  More transparency into why we make certain decisions, what initiatives we decide to address, how we hire etc.. Never been more frustrated to work here than now.

column12: I am totally bought into the idea behind holacracy and I think it could do wonders for us, but I'm skeptical that our leadership group is fully on-board. 6 months ago I was running up against executive-level micromanagement of my accountabilities, people playing politics to set project priorities, and structural changes that were forced on me by someone else's grand vision of an ideal org chart rather than as a resolution of specific tensions. The situation is unchanged today.
column13: This is an expansion of the same comment I put in the Holacracy question: I am totally bought into the idea behind holacracy and I think it could do wonders for us, but I'm skeptical that our leadership group is fully on-board. 6 months ago I was running up against executive-level micromanagement of my accountabilities, people playing politics to set project priorities, what-by-whens based on unrealistic expectations, and structural changes that were forced on me by someone else's grand vision of an ideal org chart rather than as a resolution of specific tensions. The situation is mostly unchanged today. There is so much that I could be doing to work more productively, but I'm reluctant to take responsibility given the political danger that still exists. I would like to know what our CEO is doing to hold his executives accountable to following the vision of autonomy he has set out for us, and how those executives are in turn setting the same expectations with their senior leaders. I believe these are all good people doing the best they can, but it still remains that if we have leaders operating like traditional managers we need to either coach them out of these behaviours,  or assign different lead links who can follow the company vision. Basically, create a safe environment for us on the front lines to express our autonomy.

column12: People seem more willing to share feedback with peers. The tactical meeting format has encouraged behaviours that make meetings more productive (we don't go on long tangents with fuzzy outcomes as much as before)
column13: I keep hearing that there will be more focus on spending time to improve our core product. I do see lots of work related to improving the product (which is *awesome*), but very tight deadlines for projects still seem to be the norm. We still have a long way to go in this area where the theory seems to be that we have to get things out the door quickly and we'll deal with the fallout later. We inevitably pay the price later.

column12: Tactical meetings are very helpful in having productive weekly team meetings. They help hold people accountable in their role, it provides a safe platform to express ideas, share concerns, and it assists in documenting desired outcomes that actually make change happen. I can't imagine going back to weekly team meetings without this structure.
column13: iQmetrix has a family-feel, and made me feel welcome, valued as an employee and supported. There are good opportunities for skill growth such as sessions run by HR. I would like to see more career-specific opportunities for training and development. Also, more regular, formalized feedback would be appreciated, not only the annual feedback. This would be helpful to better understand where your strengths and weaknesses lie to help understand how to improve your day-to-day work as well as continuing to progress your career based on those strengths.

column12: Processes have changed and we have improved in some way but not improved in others.
column13: It has been fun with some reasonably interesting people. There is no room for development nor learning, however. Unlike all other tech companies, we are not encouraged nor do we make it easy for motivated developers to attend conferences and learn more. IMO this is the biggest case for motivated developers with high potential to leave iQmetrix.

column12: While Holocracy has helped people to understand how teams work , what their responsibilities are, and how to help to structure the company, Holacracy does not help regarding the overall synchronization of the development methodologies among groups.
column13: iQmetrix has great people and a great culture, and it is a great place to start a career. However, I cannot see a career development in the long run because there is a very weak Career Path and Career Compensation plan in place right now. When compared to the other big names in this industry, I can see the difference.
I absolutely love working here. Some days are tough, but the people we have here and the environment we have created really make it a joy to come in.

column12: Holocracy has allowed a strong hierarchical system to come in the back door and has enabled senior positions to blindly set accountabilities, metrics, projects, and policies on others while ignoring the pain they cause.  Holocracy has also substantially removed the ability for people to work around many things that are a hindrance to their day to day effectiveness.  The system of asking others for a desired outcome and saying that it is "safe enough to try" has repeatedly resulted in people requesting outcomes from others while providing no direction on how to acheive them, which ignores whether the outcomes are actually practical to achieve.
column13: IQ was once the best place I have ever worked, that is no longer true. :(

I have an increasing frustration with the gap between iQ's fundamental culture and the trust and confidence that senior people are not giving us. I observe massive confusion across the organization every day that I'm certain accumulates to multiple hours of lost time and productivity as people are told to wait for a master plan from the executive. Individuals have said "I know what Holacracy says to do, but others aren't doing it and if I did do it then it would be bad for my career."  My "chain" of management operates with implicit expectations for my team but in Holacracy that is completely unreasonable because everything is meant to be explicit.
They value the employee of iQmetrix

column12: The metrics and checklists have been a huge improvement. As well, making the hierarchy explicit has been an improvement. iQ had ignored the hierarchy before, which was painful.
column13: iQ has a long way to go to become a software company. But some individuals in the company are trying their best to enact change. I hope they keep it up.

If iQ wants to be known as a people first company it shouldn't do further things like the layoffs of last summer where we were straight lied to by executives quite a few times. People first is the the reason that many of us work here for less than we would make other places and having that kind of experience can make it easy to decide to leave.

column12: I believe our company has seen no improvements because of Holacracy, although our company hasn't been hurt by Holacracy.  We have the same issues we've had in the past, which is that we empower people to work on whatever they feel passionate about.  I know that sounds like a positive, but we end up with a product or an environment that is unstable and unreliable.  We often hear developers say "well let's deploy this and see if anyone complains, and then we'll fix those issues", or we hear "my product is perfect and has no issues or bugs, but someone else's is continually taking down other products or services", or we hear "why do I need to follow that process?  It doesn't make sense to me" and people don't understand that the small part of the company that they work in actually impacts others... or they don't care.  We have teams/departments that actually refer to themselves as "a different company and not apart of iQmetrix".  We allow people to do what they want, when they want, and we hold no one accountable.
column13: We need to realize that we aren't a startup software company anymore, and that we need to start taking ourselves seriously as an organization.  I'm not saying the fun we have cannot continue, but hearing people say "i work hard Monday to Thursday so that I can just drink beers on Friday" in the middle of a massive client outage on a Friday has got to stop.

column12: Holacracy feels like more work with no additional benefit. It actually feels like it has made my team less productive. Also, the circle strategies are a joke. We always end up doing the same thing we've always done - whatever the executive wants whenever they want it regardless of what they told us our priorities were. Except now we spend more time arguing about how we shouldn't be doing things because they are contrary to our strategies. Strategies that are, to re-iterate, a joke.
column13: I think iQmetrix is a good place to work. What I do not understand is why we're trying to pretend like there isn't a hierarchy here. People like having a boss. If they didn't, they'd start their own company. What people don't like is being told that they have autonomy and then being passive-aggressively told what to do. If you want to tell us what to do, that's great. But just own it.
I recently completed 1 year here and it's still a great place to work.

column12: Holacracy has helped to clarify who is empowered to make decisions. However, people far enough up the chain of command seem to be free to ignore it entirely and they still put people on pet projects when it suits them.
column13: We notice when you're not there.

column12: Making things explicit is never going to be bad in my opinion. i appreciate that holocracy's main goal is to clarify work and accountabilities. I'm not sure we are good at it the majority of the time yet, but it definitely makes things better than the free-for-all we had before.
column13: i'm exhausted and stressed out and frankly generally not wanting to come here most days. simple tasks can take me days and i feel like i'm constantly aiming at a moving target with a wet noodle. Holacracy may define accountabilities and try to make work explicit but it doesn't alleviate the uphill battle of trying to move a decade deep mountain of lousy decisions in the interest of speed and it doesn't change the fact that everyone who works here is still human with all the additional complications that infers. I assume this feeling will pass if i keep throwing my body at said mountain - meaningful change takes a long time, but right now, i'm in a fragile place where i'm unhappy and feeling defeated and would easily leave to go somewhere less uphill if the opportunity came.
I love working at iQmetrix but the development and education options are extremely limited. This has lead to a feeling of stagnation in my personal and professional development.

column12: I wasnt around before holacracy. I really like how it makes it easier for me to ask questions.
column13: I feel the employees are extremely valued here and this is a close knit family with happy, engaged employees. It's been a pleasure so far.

column12: Holocracy aids only in confusion and in perpetuating the notion that individuals are only responsible for the accountabilities of their role. Holacracy devalues leadership and tries to convince individuals that they have no need for the collective, which goes against the very culture of the company.
column13: This company has amazing potential and I'm glad to be a part of that but I feel that the widespread appeal and amazing reputation iQ once had has evaporated. Holacracy has introduced a near comedic level of corporate bloat and political games that make you feel like you're in an episode of a sitcom.

column12: While our meetings are productive now, as a company I don't know how much improvement that I see.  Working between teams is still very difficult.  Most of the issues that existed before, still exist now.
column13: I really can't complain.  Nothing is awful, but very little is great.  The passion for what we do, who we are, the impact we have; it has faded.  The real excitement I hear around the office is in reference to people's "side hustles" (businesses/projects outside of iQmetrix).  Perhaps this is natural at our size.  I don't know.  I do know that the energy level within the office is low.  Apathetic seems to describe the climate.
Holacracy has not improved accountability at higher level.

column12: Glassfrog is a useful tool for managing our circle but overall it feels like we avoid holacracy at iQ. All we really do is  go to tactical meetings, which often do not seem productive.
column13: I have serious concerns with how our contribution levels are structured. There is a massive gap between intermediate and senior (or, level 2 and 3 as they are now named). The current structure also discourages people from becoming senior technically. A developer should not need to be a team lead or in another lead-of-people type position to receive the senior designation, but in practice, it seems like that's a requirement for being made 'senior' here.

column12: Maybe for some people it has improved but for others either nothing has changed or it has changed for the worse by introducing more meaningless meetings.
column13: The work we do and the people are generally all great. The company reacts relatively quickly to change. It is important to provide clear feedback from the executive level down to the product teams. I have noticed an improvement in this in the last year but we can still do better. Small things like sending a product team an email thanking them for exceptional work on projects does a lot for team moral.

Until the adoption of Holacracy I was lacking clarity and purpose as to what my role was. Holacracy has given much needed structure and communication tools to our team. It's been amazing to watch the company grow in the way it has over the past year. Excited for it to continue.

column12: We needed clearer goals at the very beginning when holacracy was introduced. It's still not clear what we're trying to achieve. Much of the change has felt like change for the sake of change. I haven't heard anyone say in person that Holacracy has made their lives easier or better. We have no real metrics, so how can we evaluate whether Holacracy is doing what we want it to do? Often it feels like Holacracy is the goal, not creating good software.
column13: I think a lot more people will leave the Vancouver office before the year is done. It used to feel like people were leaving due to factors outside the company's control. To be honest, it doesn't feel like that anymore. I know employee retention is difficult, especially in Vancouver, but maybe start trying again.
So far so good. Its early but it has been great so far.

column12: Since the implementation of Holocracy, people are more likely to 'pass the buck' and not deal with something. They'll say "it's not my circle and that person is out of office", unavailable, etc. then work gets ignored. Or work that was not assigned to a circle gets skipped over as nobody wants to take responsibility for it.  Don't get me wrong, I like the idea of holacracy it just seems that people are not extending themselves to be an extra help for others any longer.
Holacracy is just one more obstacle for the programming teams to overcome.
column13: Holacracy solves problems we don't have and ignores problems we do have.

column12: It adds clarity to what each group does.  It also highlights gaps in what we have a need for but aren't currently doing.

column13: Holacracy is an ongoing disaster for this company. Huge waste of resources spent on constant red tape and bureaucracy that slows down processes and discourages employees from trying to implement holacracy principles in their work. Teams need agile changes yet 1 or 2 people in Vancouver have the power to veto and slow down all moves as they see fit, even though they are completely removed from teams in other offices and how they work / what they need. Swallow your pride and let's go back to a method that works for us.

column12: It's the same. Nothing has changed.
Holacracy was a addition of something that was not needed

I think that Holocracy can improve any company given the right people and the right mind set. We are still working with people saying "it's not my job/accountability" which gets tossed around when people don't wan't to do the work. The old culture of just getting the work done because it needs to be done isn't remembered anymore. If you are the first to ask for something you need to be prepared to have your request moved around like a hot potato until someone takes on the accountability to solve your problem. While holocracy can speed some process up it also gives people the ability to be cold and unhelpful.

Holocracy has failed at iQ.  Despite the best efforts of the people who are passionate about it and work very hard to try to advance it, there are just far too many people in key positions who refuse to give up the power and that they had before Holocracy.  These people abuse Holocracy's tools, which sabotages the holocracy implementation and just recreates the old rank and file system we had before.  I'm not sure we can recover from this without the willingness to get rid of the holacracy rules that block the ability of lead links to assign work without a bunch of process, overhead and approval - this is the exact opposite of empowering leadership. The initial mandate of holacracy where people were told to either get on board or be let go wasn't followed through with for long-term and high level employees because many of them actively sabotage the process.
column13: Working here has become very stressful and frustrating for a lot of people here.  The constant mixed messages of saying that our priorities are one thing, then constantly doing the opposite are robbing us of our ability to create great experiences.  Some examples: saying we're focused on the Wireless market while not narrowing our resource allocation to that and at the same time opening new opportunities like the business-pitch board that diverge us even further; saying that we want better and more stable core products but immediately going against that to actively make our products worse in order to meet short deadlines for short term revenue gains; saying we want to retain our culture while actively discouraging things we've had in our culture for a long time; saying we want to adopt Holacracy while allowing people to create broad abusive domains that remove empowerment and accountability from the very people that holacracy seeks to give it to; saying circles don't equal teams while actively forcing people-based structure onto inner circles; saying that Lead Links and circles have the ability to meet their purpose how they see fit while dictating and imposing massive amounts of structure and rules about what roles can be created and how.  Most of that frustration would go away if we actually do what our strategies say we should do, even if we don't agree with those strategies. But this culture we have of product managers and lead links of the big product circles setting the strategies, then actively going against them is hugely disappointing and allows those people setting the strategies to not own the accountability of their outcome.

column12: I'm not aware of a pre-Holacracy iQmetrix so I do not have anything to compare, but compared to my last job I like the autonomy holacracy gives me.
column13: All in all, my experience has been good. There's been a lot of change which has been frustrating at times, but my overall experience has been favorable.

column12: Considering the people that have left because of holacracy in one way or another, we can't consider this an improvement.
column13: The people at iQ are the key. When people are given positions that they lack skills for, it seems there is a lot of hurt caused by this. And for as much as holacracy was supposed to be the solution for internal politicking, this doesn't seem to have worked. There's as much politics within the company as ever. When implemented, holacracy needed to have 100% buy-in from EVERYONE and that has not happened. There are lead links that continue to do their own thing and there are teams that seem to make fun of it as much as follow the tenets. I have no faith in the executive committee for a while and recent changes have not helped. There is a group of staff, shrinking all the time, keeping this work place bareable - they are driving the successes and seem to be reaping little benefit from it. It feels like there is a lot of dysfunction, top to bottom right now that makes this just another place to work instead of the enviable place it once was.

column12: Certain elements of holocracy are beneficial but the approach that some facilitators take, and the lack of adaptation to the prior iQ culture, is having a detrimental effect; many circles are trying to bypass holocracy and they are not seeing the benefits completely because of the way it's being implemented.
column13: Holacracy implementation needs another look as does the skills and abilities of the members of that circle, particularly on facilitation side; I do not feel we have made significant strides in terms of allowing decision making on all levels

column12: I agree somewhat with holcracy because I see areas of improvement within my team and a few other teams as a result of implementation. Personally, I am finding it empowering and clarifying as does my team.  However, I see there are breakdowns occurring between teams who are not embracing it; some teams are using holocratic practices and continuing to use their old processes. Thus, it feels like we now have two sets of "rules" to operate by within the organization, which is causing tension and stress when working with some teams that are holacratic and some that are non-holocratic.
column13: Leadership needs to model the way more transparently on how to use holacracy.  Provide more frequent communications on changes to the organizational structure and share stories on how the executive are using it.  Having our leadership show us they have embraced the practices will make it more likely that others will follow suit.

column12: To be fair, it might take more than 1 year before the Holacracy process begins to bear fruit - but specific to my team, the Holacracy process has felt negative and detrimental. I feel like the process of organizing circles has resulted in social / hierarchical / political manoeuvering and game-playing. It might be that the process of defining and resolving tensions might eventually clean this up and improve it, I don't know.
column13: iQmetrix is a great place. It feels a bit strained at the moment due to having to cope (maybe truly for the first time) with not having explosive growth in revenue. It might have been compounded a bit by undergoing a fairly drastic change in implementing Holacracy at the same time. There is certainly still promise here to return to growth with new products so there's still reason to be optimistic.

I run into fewer people who are passionate dreamers who inspire others. There seems to be less room for them here. I am impressed with the decision to embrace Holacracy, it is the right direction to go. I am concerned for the future of iQmetrix but will be working hard to help wherever I can.

column12: It is not clear to me at all that Holacracy has improved anything at all. I see many teams working in silos, and if anything it seems Holacracy has reinforced this by giving everyone the right to do what they want to as they see fit.
I was not with the company before holacracy but it works well in my circle.
column13: Teams are working in silos. Teams would benefit from scrutiny by a Chief Technology Officer, which we need but don't have.

column12: My day-to-day work is plagued with poor work prioritization, insufficient resources, and a lack of training. When Holacracy was introduced, it was implied it would help us identify where we needed better prioritization, resources, and training. So far, the outcomes has been an increase in resources for one circle and the elimination of a few of our services. Despite these great changes, I have not seen any improvement in my day-to-day experience.
column13: The day-to-day experience of your technical employees have been deteriorating for a few years now. I understand it hasn't been an easy time for our company, but I have little faith in our leadership to handle these changes in the long term. If we are to continue being a software company, I recommend that our leadership re-evaluate how they manage technical people.

column12: Maybe holacracy has been beneficial because it's the kind of system that allows those who are normally talked over (and have to fight to be heard) a chance to speak during tacticals.
column13: Let's make sure we value and retain our best people. I like to think that I do my best no matter what my environment is. However, I could see how an amazing employee might never thrive if not surrounded by great people. I think the opposite is true too, if we had a sub-par person surrounded by an excellent team, they can't help but improve. I worry that the high quality people around me will soon realize that they can't stay just because they like the people, and my work days will be sad after they leave.

column12: I wished that it was followed more consistently by everyone because occasionally there still seems to be a lot of politics.
column13: There are some people that use Holacracy as a way to avoid work that other circles need and this causes issues with client satisfaction.

column12: I think the resources (money and employees) spent on Holocracy implementation could be put to better use in other places (compensation, hiring more people).
It's helped in some areas and hindered in others.
